The parijat is a special flower in Maharashtra: it falls by itself, cannot be plucked, and is associated with dawn devotion. concepts.title: The Parijat (рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрдХреНрдд) тАФ Night Jasmine Flower
concepts.content: The parijat (рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрдХреНрдд), also known as night jasmine (botanical name: Nyctanthes arbor-tristis), is a beloved flower in Maharashtra and across India. It has small, delicate white petals with a bright orange/saffron-coloured hollow stem. The flower has a beautiful, gentle fragrance. What makes the parijat truly special is that it falls from the tree by itself тАФ you cannot pluck it from the branch. It falls overnight or at dawn, carpeting the ground with white and orange. This is why it is associated with purity, devotion, and the quiet beauty of early morning (рдкрд╣рд╛рдЯ). The parijat is used in worship (рдкреВрдЬрд╛) offerings to Gods, particularly to Lord Vishnu.

examples.text: The parijat flower is tiny тАФ smaller than a rupee coin тАФ but its fragrance fills an entire garden.
It blooms and falls at night/dawn тАФ the morning ground beneath a parijat tree is covered in white flowers.
Used in Hindu puja (worship) тАФ collecting fallen parijat flowers for puja is a morning ritual in many Maharashtra homes.
The orange hollow stem is distinctive тАФ it makes the white petals look like tiny cups on orange stalks.

keyPoints: рдкреНрд░рд╛рдЬрдХреНрдд = parijat = night jasmine тАФ small white fragrant flower with orange hollow stem.
Special quality: it falls by itself тАФ you cannot pluck it from the branch.
It blooms and falls at night and dawn тАФ morning courtyards are carpeted with fallen flowers.
Used in puja (worship) as an offering to Gods, especially Lord Vishnu.
Associated with: purity, devotion, dawn (рдкрд╣рд╛рдЯ), and gentle beauty.

It was brought to Earth by Lord Krishna and planted in his wife Satyabhama's garden тАФ a mythological story that shows how special this flower is!

concepts.title: Poem Meaning тАФ Flowers Falling Gently
concepts.content: The poem 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН рдкрдбрддреА' describes the gentle, delicate falling of parijat flowers onto a person тАФ 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН рдкрдбрддреА рдЕрдВрдЧрд╛рд╡рд░рддреА' (they fall drop by drop onto the body). The flowers fall with the lightness of drops (рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН), tickling and touching the person's skin. The poet captures the quiet joy of standing under a parijat tree at dawn, feeling the gentle rain of fragrant flowers. The poem creates a mood of peaceful, devotional morning тАФ cool air, fragrant flowers falling, the world just waking up. It is a meditation on the quiet beauty that nature offers freely every morning.

examples.text: Imagine standing in a courtyard at dawn тАФ cool air, birds chirping, and white fragrant flowers falling on you.
'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' тАФ the repetition creates the rhythm of drops, making you feel the gentle touch of falling flowers.
The mood of the poem is calm, peaceful, and devotional тАФ like the feeling of morning prayer.
The poem has a musical quality тАФ 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' creates a gentle beat that matches the soft falling of flowers.

keyPoints: 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН рдкрдбрддреА рдЕрдВрдЧрд╛рд╡рд░рддреА' тАФ flowers fall drop by drop onto the body, like gentle rain.
The poem captures the magic of early morning (рдкрд╣рд╛рдЯ) under a parijat tree.
The mood is peaceful, devotional, and joyful тАФ a celebration of simple natural beauty.
The repetition of 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' creates rhythm and a musical feel in the poem.
Marathi poetry often celebrates the quiet, everyday moments of nature тАФ this is a beautiful example.
concepts.funFact: Maharashtra's morning culture (рдкрд╣рд╛рдЯ рд╕рдВрд╕реНрдХреГрддреА) is unique тАФ many people wake before sunrise for daily worship, yoga, walks, and to collect parijat flowers for puja. The Warkari devotees (those who go on pilgrimage to Pandharpur) wake at 3-4 AM and sing devotional songs (рднрдЬрди) тАФ the parijat-scented dawn is deeply spiritual for them.

concepts.title: Nature Imagery in Marathi Poetry
concepts.content: Marathi poetry has a rich tradition of using nature images (рдирд┐рд╕рд░реНрдЧ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдорд╛) тАФ flowers, rivers, rain, seasons, birds, trees тАФ to express human emotions and ideas. The parijat poem is a perfect example: the falling flowers are not just flowers тАФ they are a symbol of grace, gentleness, and divine blessing. In Marathi literature (from the ancient Varkari saints like Dnyaneshwar and Tukaram to modern poets), nature is not just a background but an active participant in human life. The monsoon (рдкрд╛рдКрд╕), the mango tree (рдЖрдВрдмрд╛), the basil plant (рддреБрд│рд╕), the bullock, the parijat тАФ all are characters in Marathi literature.

examples.text: Monsoon (рдкрд╛рдКрд╕) in Marathi poetry тАФ represents hope, renewal, longing, and the joy of life returning to dry earth.
Harvest fields (рд╢реЗрдд) тАФ symbol of hard work, abundance, and the cycle of seasons in Marathi rural poetry.
Flowers тАФ parijat, mogra, jai, rose тАФ each carries specific meanings in Marathi poetry and culture.
Birds тАФ sparrow (рдЪрд┐рдордгреА), cuckoo (рдХреЛрдХрд┐рд│рд╛), crow (рдХрд╛рд╡рд│рд╛) тАФ common characters in Marathi poems and folk songs.

keyPoints: Nature imagery (рдирд┐рд╕рд░реНрдЧ рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдорд╛) is central to Marathi poetry tradition.
Common nature images: рдкрд╛рдКрд╕ (monsoon), рдлреВрд▓ (flower), рдирджреА (river), рдЭрд╛рдб (tree), рдкрдХреНрд╖реА (bird).
Nature in Marathi poetry is not just decoration тАФ it is a symbol and participant in human emotions.
Marathi Saints like Dnyaneshwar, Tukaram, and Janabai used nature images to express devotion.
Understanding nature imagery helps students read and appreciate Marathi poems deeply.
concepts.funFact: Sant Dnyaneshwar (13th century, Alandi, Maharashtra) wrote 'Pasayadan' тАФ considered the greatest prayer in Marathi literature тАФ in which he wishes for the whole world to become like a garden of blooming plants and all people to live like bees gathering sweetness. His poetry is full of nature images!

concepts.title: Poetic Device: рдзреНрд╡рдирд┐ рдЕрдиреБрдХрд░рдг (Onomatopoeia)
concepts.content: Onomatopoeia (рдзреНрд╡рдирд┐ рдЕрдиреБрдХрд░рдг) is a literary device where a word imitates or sounds like the sound it describes. In Marathi, this is called 'рдзреНрд╡рдирд┐ рдЕрдиреБрдХрд░рдг' (dhvani anukaraN) тАФ dhvani means sound and anukaraN means imitation. In the poem, 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' imitates the soft sound of drops falling. This makes the poem more vivid and sensory тАФ you can almost hear the flowers falling when you read or hear the poem. Marathi literature and folk songs are rich in such sound-imitating words.

examples.text: 'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' тАФ imitates the sound of drops or small objects falling softly (flowers, rain drops on leaves).
'рднреВрдВ рднреВрдВ' тАФ imitates the buzzing sound of a bee or insect.
'рдЫрдкреН рдЫрдкреН' тАФ imitates the sound of splashing in water (walking through puddles, playing in rain).
'рд╕рд░рд╕рд░' тАФ imitates the sound of wind rustling through leaves or paper being moved quickly.

keyPoints: рдзреНрд╡рдирд┐ рдЕрдиреБрдХрд░рдг = onomatopoeia тАФ words that imitate the sound they describe.
'рдЯрдкреН рдЯрдкреН' in the poem imitates the soft sound of drops/flowers falling gently.
Other Marathi examples: рднреВрдВ рднреВрдВ (bee), рдЫрдкреН рдЫрдкреН (splash), рдЧреБрд░рдЧреБрд░ (growling/thunder), рд╕рд░рд╕рд░ (rustling).
Onomatopoeia makes poetry more vivid and sensory тАФ readers can almost hear what is being described.
Marathi folk songs (рд▓реЛрдХрдЧреАрдд) and children's songs are especially rich in onomatopoeic words.
concepts.funFact: Marathi has some wonderful onomatopoeic words! 'рдЦрд│рдЦрд│' imitates the sound of water flowing over pebbles in a brook. 'рдЧрдбрдЧрдб' imitates thunder. 'рдХрд┐рд░рдХрд┐рд░' imitates a child's whining or a door creaking. These words are so expressive that even someone who doesn't know the language can guess their meaning from the sound!

realWorldExamples: Parijat trees in Maharashtra homes: Many Maharashtra families plant a parijat tree in their courtyard for daily worship. Collecting fallen flowers every morning is a common devotional practice.
